summary: The U.S. District Court for the Southern District of California today entered a final judgment against San Diego Gas & Electric Co. ("SDG&E") for failing to comply with the company's design and specification requirements for natural gas systems at Camp Pendleton, California.  According to the SEC's complaint, filed on September 12, 2017, an Assault Amphibious Vehicle struck and injured fifteen Marines while riding in the vehicle.  The complaint alleges that SDG & E failed to maintain the gas line and failed to adequately mark and mark it as in compliance with the requirements.  As alleged in the complaint, SDG and E violated Rule 12(b)(7) of the federal securities laws by failing to provide sufficient information to the court as to whether the company was a necessary and indispensable party.  In a parallel action, the United States Attorney's Office for the Central District of New York today announced criminal charges against SDG, E.O.C. and E.L.D. Cal., charging SDG with violations of the antifraud provisions of Section 10(b) and Rule 10b-5 thereunder of the Securities Exchange Act of 1934.  Without admitting or denying the allegations in the SEC’s complaint, the defendants consented to the entry of a judgment that permanently enjoins SDG from violating the charged provisions and orders it to pay disgorgement, prejudgment interest, and a civil penalty equal to the amount of the civil penalty.  San Diego &E also agreed to pay a $10,000 civil penalty and a $20,000 officer-and-director bar.  Additionally, the settlement is subject to court approval.  For further information, see Litigation Release No. 5:08-cv-877-JF (9th Cir. 2005).  The SEC's Office of Investor Education and Advocacy has issued anÂ Investor AlertÂ to encourage investors to check the background of anyone selling or offering them an investment using the free and simple search tool on Investor.gov.  Investors can also use theÂ SEC'sÂ investor.govÂ feature to quickly identify whether they are registered professionals or professionals. Â The SEC's Complaint, filed in federal district court in Los Angeles, charges SDG as a necessary party because it failed to meet the requirements under Rule 12. The complaint seeks a permanent injunction, civil penalties, and an injunction against future violations of Section 13(a)(1) and 13(c).  In its investigation, the SEC has conducted a parallel investigation, which is ongoing.   The case is being supervised by Eric R. Werner and supervised by
